stem: The nurse reviews the 07:00 progress note for a client admitted with acute decompensated heart failure. Select the findings that indicate the client is experiencing fluid volume overload.
passage:
07:00 Nurses' Note
S: Client reports a significant increase in shortness of breath over the last hour, stating 'I feel like I'm drowning.' He is visibly anxious.
B: The client has a known [history of coronary artery disease] and hypertension. He confirms non-adherence with his home medication, [furosemide 40 mg PO daily], for the past several days. He lives alone in a third-floor apartment without an elevator, which presents a barrier to regular follow-up appointments.
A: Vital signs are concerning: [BP 160/90 mmHg (MAP 113)], [HR 110 bpm], [RR 28/min], and [SpO2 90% on 2L NC]. Cardiac telemetry shows sinus tachycardia. Auscultation of the lungs reveals [bibasilar crackles] bilaterally. Physical exam is positive for [jugular vein distention (JVD)] at 45 degrees. There is [3+ pitting edema] in bilateral lower extremities. Morning weight is 90 kg, a [weight gain of 5 kg] from his documented weight of 85 kg one week ago. The [client appears anxious and restless].
R: Furosemide 40 mg IV was administered at 07:15 per STAT order. The provider has been notified of the client's status and new orders are anticipated. Will continue to monitor respiratory status and urine output closely.

tabs.title: Clinical Feed
tabs.content:
Admission Note
Time: 03:00
S: Client is a 68-year-old male presenting to the ED with a chief complaint of worsening shortness of breath and leg swelling over the past week. He states, 'I can't catch my breath, even when I'm just sitting.'
B: Client has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and heart failure diagnosed 2 years ago. Home medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, and furosemide, but he admits to 'forgetting' his furosemide for several days. He lives alone in a third-floor walk-up apartment, which is a barrier to mobility and follow-up care.
A: On admission, client was tachypneic and required 2L of oxygen via nasal cannula to maintain SpO2 >92%. Mild bibasilar crackles noted on auscultation. 2+ pitting edema in lower extremities. Alert and oriented x4. Appears fatigued.
R: Admitted to the medical-surgical unit for management of acute decompensated heart failure. Placed on continuous cardiac and pulse oximetry monitoring. Strict intake and output monitoring initiated. Awaiting lab results and provider orders.

Progress Note
Time: 07:00
S: Client reports a significant increase in shortness of breath over the last hour, stating 'I feel like I'm drowning.' He is visibly anxious.
B: The client has a known history of coronary artery disease and hypertension. He confirms non-adherence with his home medication, furosemide 40 mg PO daily, for the past several days. He lives alone in a third-floor apartment without an elevator, which presents a barrier to regular follow-up appointments.
A: Vital signs are concerning: BP 160/90 mmHg (MAP 113), HR 110 bpm, RR 28/min, and SpO2 90% on 2L NC. Cardiac telemetry shows sinus tachycardia. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bibasilar crackles bilaterally. Physical exam is positive for jugular vein distention (JVD) at 45 degrees. There is 3+ pitting edema in bilateral lower extremities. Morning weight is 90 kg, a weight gain of 5 kg from his documented weight of 85 kg one week ago. The client appears anxious and restless.
R: Furosemide 40 mg IV was administered at 07:15 per STAT order. The provider has been notified of the client's status and new orders are anticipated. Will continue to monitor respiratory status and urine output closely.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Performed at 07:00
Cardiovascular: Tachycardia with S3 gallop noted. Jugular vein distention (JVD) present at 45-degree angle. 3+ pitting edema noted bilaterally from feet to mid-shin. Capillary refill <3 seconds.
Respiratory: Increased work of breathing with use of accessory muscles. Bibasilar crackles auscultated throughout lower lung fields. Tachypneic.
Neurological: Alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Appears anxious and restless. Follows commands.
Gastrointestinal: Bowel sounds normoactive in all four quadrants. Abdomen soft, non-distended.

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content:
Test: Chest X-ray (Portable, AP view)
Date: Today at 03:30
Indication: Shortness of breath, suspected heart failure exacerbation.
Findings: The cardiac silhouette is enlarged. There is evidence of pulmonary vascular congestion with bilateral interstitial edema and small pleural effusions, more prominent on the right. No evidence of focal consolidation, pneumothorax, or significant atelectasis.
Impression: Findings are consistent with acute pulmonary edema and cardiomegaly, suggestive of decompensated congestive heart failure.

content.Action: Continuous cardiac and pulse oximetry monitoring

rationale.correct: The selected findings are classic indicators of fluid volume overload in acute decompensated heart failure. Increased hydrostatic pressure from a failing left ventricle causes fluid to back up into the pulmonary circulation (bibasilar crackles, hypoxemia) and the systemic venous system (JVD, peripheral edema). The body's compensatory mechanisms, like the sympathetic nervous system, increase heart rate and blood pressure. Rapid weight gain is the most sensitive indicator of fluid retention.
rationale.incorrect: The unselected findings represent background historical data (history of CAD), home medications (furosemide PO), or non-specific symptoms (anxiety). While relevant to the client's overall condition, they are not direct, objective assessment findings that confirm current fluid volume overload.

answerBreakdown.content: Incorrect. A history of coronary artery disease is a significant risk factor and underlying cause for heart failure, but it is part of the client's medical background, not an acute finding of current fluid overload.

Incorrect. The client's prescription for furosemide is a historical detail about his treatment plan. His non-adherence is a likely cause of the current exacerbation, but the medication itself is not a clinical sign of fluid overload.

Correct. Hypertension (BP 160/90 mmHg) in ADHF is often due to increased systemic vascular resistance and sympathetic nervous system activation as the body tries to compensate for decreased cardiac output. It also reflects the increased intravascular volume.

Correct. Tachycardia (HR 110 bpm) is a compensatory response to maintain cardiac output when stroke volume is impaired by the failing ventricle. The heart beats faster to try to circulate the excess fluid volume.
Correct. Tachypnea (RR 28/min) is a direct result of pulmonary congestion and hypoxemia. Fluid in the alveoli impairs gas exchange, stimulating respiratory centers to increase the rate of breathing.

Correct. Low oxygen saturation (SpO2 90% on 2L NC) indicates impaired gas exchange at the alveolar-capillary membrane. This is caused by fluid shifting into the alveoli (pulmonary edema), creating a barrier to oxygen diffusion.

Correct. Bibasilar crackles are adventitious lung sounds caused by the popping open of small airways and alveoli that were collapsed by fluid. This is a hallmark sign of left-sided heart failure and pulmonary edema.

Correct. Jugular vein distention (JVD) is a key indicator of increased central venous pressure. It reflects fluid backing up into the systemic venous circulation due to right ventricular failure or severe left ventricular failure.

Correct. Pitting edema is the accumulation of excess fluid in the interstitial spaces of dependent tissues, such as the lower extremities. It is a classic sign of systemic fluid overload and right-sided heart failure.
Correct. A rapid weight gain of 5 kg (11 lbs) in one week is the most sensitive indicator of fluid retention. Each kilogram of weight gain corresponds to approximately one liter of retained fluid.

Incorrect. While anxiety and restlessness are common in clients with ADHF due to hypoxemia and dyspnea ('air hunger'), they are non-specific symptoms and not direct physiological indicators of fluid volume status.

clinicalPearls: An S3 heart sound ('ventricular gallop') is a classic auscultatory finding in heart failure, caused by the rapid filling of a noncompliant, volume-overloaded ventricle.
Daily weights are the most reliable method for monitoring short-term changes in fluid status. A gain of >2 lbs (0.9 kg) in 24 hours or >5 lbs (2.3 kg) in a week is a critical finding.

B-type Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) is a hormone released by ventricular myocytes in response to stretching. A level >100 pg/mL is indicative of heart failure, and levels often exceed 1000 pg/mL in acute decompensation.
rationale.questionTrap: A common trap is confusing background information or risk factors (like 'history of CAD') with acute clinical cues. To avoid this, focus only on the objective data from the current assessment that directly reflects the client's present physiological state.

mnemonic.title: FACES of Heart Failure
mnemonic.expansion:
F: Fatigue
A: Activity limitation
C: Congestion/Cough
E: Edema
S: Shortness of breath
